The production of hydrogen from dry reforming of methane (DRM) is crucial for the energy transition, aiming for a more sustainable energy matrix due to its similarity to biogas reforming, which provides a renewable substrate for large-scale synthesis gas production. In this context, the efficiency of catalysts plays a fundamental role in optimizing this process, considering the extreme operational conditions in terms of temperature and competing reactions. This study investigates the synthesis, characterization, and stability of nickel catalysts supported on alumina, using a one-pot synthetic approach via microwave-assisted combustion, compared to catalysts synthesized by the commonly used wet impregnation method. Structural characterization was performed using X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR-H2). Textural properties were assessed through nitrogen (N2) adsorption. The results showed that the catalysts synthesized by the one-pot method tend to have a high dispersion of nickel particles and a larger surface area, contributing to superior catalytic activity. Catalytic stability tests revealed that the catalysts promoted with B2O3 exhibited lower deactivation and reduced coke formation compared to unpromoted catalysts; however, an increase in the amount of B2O3 raised deactivation due to sintering, which was mitigated by the one-pot method that enhances metal-support interaction. The one-pot synthetized nickel catalyst with 2.5 wt% stood out, with stability more than ten times greater than that of the conventional Ni/Al2O3 catalyst and four times greater than the promoted catalyst synthesized via impregnation. Among the 3 catalysts mentioned, the final CH4 conversions were 78 %, 72 %, and 75 %, respectively, while the H2 yields were 60 %, 55 %, and 58 % after 12 h of reaction. The findings indicate that promotion with B2O3 and the one-pot synthesis significantly improved the stability and efficiency of the catalysts, offering potential for larger-scale synthesis gas production applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords One-pot synthesis Dry reforming Boron Promoter Coke Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The emission of gases which aggravate the greenhouse effect such as CO2 and CH4 has caused drastic changes in the global climate [1]; in turn, the need to reverse this process aiming to preserve the global ecosystem [2], as well as cities [3], has demanded an effort from all sectors of human activity. The energy sector is no exception, as it is still largely based on fossil sources with a high carbon footprint. Therefore, this sector has sought alternatives to reduce its emissions [4] such as biomass [5–7], wind energy [8,9] and solar energy [10,11], aiming at the long-term sustainability of its activities. Hydrogen (H2) has emerged as an interesting alternative to fossil fuels for energy generation [12] mainly for the transport sector due to its low toxicity and the high conversion efficiencies of fuel cells [13]. In addition, it is a molecule which can be obtained from different sources, whether through fossil sources such as natural gas using the reforming and water displacement reactions [14,15] or renewable sources such as biogas and water using the reforming biogas process [16,17]. Similar to the dry reforming of methane (DRM) and water electrolysis, electrolytic attainment of H2 has a higher cost [12] than obtaining it via reforming reactions, as is the case of biogas reforming. The main obstacle to implementing reforming CH4 with CO2 are the catalysts used in the process, which tend to quickly deactivate due to the coating of active sites with coke, as well as the sintering of active phase particles due to the high temperature required in the process [18]. In this aspect, several approaches have been proposed to improve the performance of catalysts for DRM, such as adding promoters in the catalyst formulation [16,17,19], impregnation methods, and new synthesis methods [20,21] aiming to improve resistance to coke formation and sintering. The active metals in DRM are divided into noble metals (Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir, and Pt) and non-noble metals (Co and Ni) [22]. Noble metals exhibit high performance, dispersion, and resistance to coke formation, making them efficient and stable catalysts. However, the main issue with these metals is their high cost [23,24], Given the high cost, non-noble alternatives, such as nickel and cobalt, have been extensively tested. The issue with using cobalt is its oxidation during DRM, leading to the loss of active sites. On the other hand, nickel achieves performance close to that of noble metal catalysts in terms of conversion but catalyzes parallel reactions leading to coke formation [18,25,26], Leading to its deactivation either by coke encapsulation or by particle breakdown due to the growth of filamentous carbon [27]. Considering the cost, many studies aim to mitigate the issues of nickel-based catalysts by exploring different active metal systems, supports, and promoters, with the goal of incorporating properties that enhance conversion, selectivity, and resistance to catalyst deactivation [22]. The main nickel-based catalyst systems for DRM consist of the active phase supported on silica (SiO2) or alumina (Al2O3). Silica, as a support, has a high surface area, which leads to greater dispersion of the metallic phase, providing more active sites and consequently a higher initial conversion [28], This decreases during the DRM process due to the sintering of the active phase particles, caused by the weak metal-support interaction between Ni and SiO2, as well as rapid deactivation due to the formation of carbonaceous species [22]. The use of supports with ordered pore structures, such as SBA-15 [29] The aluminosilicate MCM-41 can, due to its properties, mitigate the issues associated with common silica by confining nickel particles within its pore system, while maintaining high dispersion thanks to its surface area. [30]. In this regard, alumina is presented as a thermally stable support in its α phase, with a Ni-Al2O3 interaction superior to that of silica, mitigating the sintering process. However, its low surface area leads to lower dispersion, reducing the availability of active sites, which are quickly encapsulated by the coke formed during DRM. [18,31–33]. An alternative to the low surface area of α-alumina is the use of alumina in its metastable γ phase, which has a higher surface area and ensures greater dispersion, without losing the metal-support interaction of the α phase (including the possibility of NiAl2O4 formation), resulting in a catalyst with greater resistance to sintering [22]. Due to the acidity of alumina as a support, the dissociation of CH4 is enhanced, while CO2 adsorption is hindered. Similarly, mechanisms for coke gasification, such as the reverse Boudouard reaction (Eq. (1)), which depend on oxygen from CO2 conversion, lead to a high formation of inorganic carbon [34,35]. (1) CO2 + C → 2CO (ΔH°298 = +172.0 kJ.mol-1) Regarding coke formation resistance in Ni/Al2O3 systems, several promoters stand out, such as cerium, lanthanum, magnesium, and potassium. Most of these promoters focus on modifying the acidity of the alumina support, as is the case with La, Mg, and K, as observed in the work by Al-Mubaddel et al. (2021) [35] Where the insertion of La was able to better control methane decomposition, reducing coke production. As demonstrated in the work by Son et al. (2014) [36] graphitization of carbon was reduced with the insertion of Mg as a promoter, decreasing the formation of encapsulating carbon. In catalysts promoted by K, the formation of basic sites provides greater efficiency in the reverse Boudouard reaction (Eq. (1)), improving carbon gasification [37]. Cerium, on the other hand, acts by increasing basicity and, due to its oxygen vacancies caused by the transition from Ce4+ to Ce3+, has a high capacity for oxygen storage, improving the gasification of the formed coke [38]. Another promising promoter is boron; as a promoter of DRM, it was initially studied by computational methods where it was proposed that it prevents the diffusion and growth of carbon particles by settling in the octahedral vacancies of nickel particles [39,40]. Experimental works such as those by Fouskas et al. (2014) [41]; Singh, et al. (2020) [29] and Shakir et al. (2022) [42,43] they confirmed this property and demonstrated the high capacity to suppress coke, similar to or greater than that of more expensive promoters such as rare earth metals. However, the major drawback of its application as a promoter is that boron increases the energy for the methane dehydrogenation reaction in the (111) plane by 12 kJ.mol-1 [39], in addition to causing a decrease in metal-support interaction, which results in greater sintering with high amounts of boron [44]. The synthesis methods used can strongly affect the performance of the catalyst; Dekkar et al. (2020) [45] performed the microemulsion synthesis of Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/SiO2 catalysts and found that this provided better textural properties and smaller particle size than the impregnation method, but led to such a high metal-support interaction that it impaired the reducibility of the catalyst, leading to lower conversion. Moreover, Gurav et al. (2017) [46] evaluated the co-precipitation, citrate gel and impregnation methods, finding the best results for the co-precipitation method, with the smallest sizes of nickel crystallites, a lower amount of inorganic carbon and metal-support interaction which enables a greater degree of reduction for nickel particles. Aiming for greater dispersion of the active phase and reduction in synthesis time and costs, Medeiros et al. (2021) [47] adopted the one-pot method in which the catalyst is directly synthesized without subsequent impregnation steps, resulting in a catalyst with a high specific surface area, resistance to coke formation and high stability. Taking into account the properties necessary for catalysts for DRM, this work presents a comparison between Ni/Al2O3 catalysts promoted by B2O3 synthesized by the one-pot method in microwave-assisted combustion and by the incipient moisture impregnation method, aiming to add resistance to coke formation provided by the promoter and the synthesis method, in turn producing catalysts with high stability for application in the dry reforming of methane. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts will be named based on the synthesis method used, such as impregnation nickel (IMN). For the catalysts with B2O3, the letter B is added followed by the mass percentage, thus with 2.5 wt% of B2O3 (IMNB-25) and with 5 wt% (IMNB-5). For the catalysts synthesized by the one-pot microwave combustion method, the acronym MONB is used followed by the amount of B2O3. The MONB-25 and MONB-5 catalysts with the respective compositions of Ni12.5 %B2O3 2.5 %/Al2O3 and Ni10 %B2O3 5 %/Al2O3 were synthesized by the microwave-assisted combustion method using a similar one-pot approach to that carried out by Medeiros et al. (2021) [47] in which the nitrates of nickel hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Sigma Aldrich), aluminum nonhydrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O, ISOFAR) and boric acid (H3BO3, REAGEN) were dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water next to urea fuel (CO(NH2)2, ISOFAR), which was used in a proportion of 0.5 mol in relation to the reaction stoichiometry for total oxidation of the precursors. All calculations for combustion in this work followed the fundamentals of the chemistry of explosives and propellants [48]. For supported catalysts called IMN, IMNB-25 and IMNB-5 (with their respective compositions of: Ni15 %/Al2O3, Ni12.5 %B2O3 2.5 %/Al2O3 and Ni10 %B2O3 5 %/Al2O3), the support was synthesized by the microwave-assisted combustion method following the synthesis methodology used by Maziviero et al. (2021) [32] Dissolution occurred in 10 mL of deionized water under magnetic stirring of Al(NO3)3·9H2O together with the fuel CO(NH2)2, using half the stoichiometric amount of fuel in order to obtain the gamma phase of alumina. The mixture was then taken to a microwave adapted for the combustion process using a power of 450 W for 5 min, and the resulting powder was calcined in an oven for 3 h at 550 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C.min-1. The active phase and promoter were inserted through incipient moisture impregnation, where (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and H3BO3 were mixed with the synthesized support and dissolved with the nitrate hydration water, resulting in a mixture with a paste texture. This mixture was subsequently dried in an oven for 15 h at 60 °C and then calcined at 550 °C for 3 h at a heating rate of 10 °C.min-1. The composition of all the catalysts was determined by the design of experiments (DOE) method using a mixture design for the two components%Ni and%B2O3. [49]. 2.2 Characterization The catalysts were structurally characterized by x-ray diffraction (XRD). The diffractograms were obtained using a Shimadzu XRD 7000 diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) at 30 Kv and 30 mA, scanning the range from 2θ = 10 to 80° with a step of 0.02° and a scanning speed of 2°.min-1. The average crystallite size was calculated by the Scherrer equation [50]. The crystalline phases were determined by the Rietveld refinement method using the Maud version 2.76 software program. Considering that the boron phases are not crystalline and do not present diffraction peaks in the XRD analysis, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was used to characterize the boron phases formed. The spectra were obtained in a Shimadzu IRAffinity-1 spectroscope with a Miracle ATR system manufactured by PIKE Technologies, and the analyzes were performed with a scan from 4000 cm-1 to 400 cm-1. The N2 physisorption isotherms were obtained using a Micromeritics ASAP2020 adsorption analyzer at a temperature of −196.15 °C. The specific surface area was obtained using the BET method, while the pore diameter was measured using the BJH method for the desorption isotherm. The reducibility of the materials was confirmed through a temperature-programmed reduction (TPR-H2) test conducted using equipment manufactured by Micromeritics, model Autochem II 2920, over a temperature range of 20 °C to 800 °C, utilizing 50 mg of analyte and a gas mixture containing 10 % H2 and 90 % N2. The carbon formed after the reaction was evaluated using RAMAN spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM). RAMAN spectra were obtained on a HORIBA LabRam Evolution spectrometer with maximum power using a 90 mW laser and a wavelength of 633 nm, while the TGA tests were conducted on Shimadzu DTG-60 thermal analyzer under synthetic air flow (50 mL.min-1) and alumina crucibles. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) micrographs were obtained on a Zeiss Auriga SEM. 2.3 Catalytic stability test DRM stability tests were conducted in a catalytic unit with a tubular fixed bed reactor made of U-shaped quartz with a volume of 6 mL in the space designated for the catalytic bed. The unit was coupled to a Varian CP3800 gaseous chromatograph (GC) inside a programmable oven. The gases were detected using thermal conductivity (TCD), in which the catalysts were activated at 700 °C for 1 h under a gaseous mixture flow containing 10 % H2 in N2 with a flow of 20 mL.min-1. After activation, a purge with N2 was used for 5 min under a flow of 30 mL.min-1. The DRM reaction was performed with a gas mixture containing 10 % CH4 and CO2 in 80 % N2 under a flow of 40 mL.min-1, providing a spatial velocity of 96 L.g-1.h-1. The CH4 and CO2 conversion values, H2 and CO yield, H2/CO ratio and deactivation were calculated by Eqs. (2) to (7). (2) conv ( C H 4 ) = ( C H 4 ) in . Initial Conv . × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of catalysts All synthesized materials presented diffraction patterns (Fig. 1 ) referring to the γ-alumina phase, attested by peaks in the 2θ region at 37.1° (311), 45.80° (400) and 66.90° (440), and confirmed by the standard PDF 01–080–1385 crystallographic chart. The phase presents cubic symmetry with space group Fd-3 m, while the observed diffraction pattern resembles that found in works by Maziviero et al. (2021) [32] and Ai et al. (2023) [51]. The IMN and IMNB-25 materials clearly present the nickel oxide (NiO) peaks at 2θ = 37.20° referring to the plane (111), 43.30° referring to the plane (200), 62.90° referring to the plane (311), and 75.40° referring to the plane (021), as confirmed by the PDF 01–078–0643 crystallographic chart. The IMNB-5, MONB-25 and MONB-5 materials show a marked reduction in the intensity of these peaks similar to that observed in the work by Fouskas et al. (2014) [41] which is due to the greater dispersion of nickel particles caused by the presence of B2O3, given its ability to restrict the size of metallic particles and this effect is observed with the increase in the mass percentage of B2O3 [41,52,53] by settling in the crystalline lattice vacancies of these particles [39,40,54]. Another relevant aspect regarding the absence of NiO peaks in the MONB-25 and MONB-5 catalysts is the dispersion inherent to the synthesis method, as observed in the work of Medeiros et al. (2021) [47] with the simultaneous dissolution and formation of the active phase precursor (NiO), support and promoter in the combustion reaction. This guarantees high dispersion of the precursors until forming the catalyst, differing from what occurs in the impregnation processes where the precursors are restricted to the surface of the support. The loss of peak intensity related to the NiO phase in these catalysts indicate superior particle dispersion of this phase, corroborating what was obtained for the average crystallite size (Table 1 ), in which the catalysts synthesized through one-pot synthesis have a smaller crystallite size [47,55]. Evaluating the diffraction pattern for the materials after the reduction step, forming the catalysts (Fig. 2 ), the formation of the metallic nickel phase is observed, confirmed by the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 45°, 52°, and 76.5° and by the crystallographic card PDF 01–087–0712. All the catalysts show peaks related to the γ-phase of alumina, following the pattern observed before reduction. However, the IMN catalyst presents peaks related to the α-alumina phase, demonstrating that a phase transition occurs at the reduction temperature, as observed by Maziviero et al. (2021) [32,56]. The presence of the alpha phase was confirmed by the peaks at 2θ = 26°, 35.1°, 43°, 52.6°, 57.6°, and 68° and by the crystallographic card PDF 01–071–1683. The phase change can affect the catalyst's performance during its reduction, as the α-phase tends to have a lower surface area compared to the γ-phase [57]. Despite its thermal stability, the formation of the α-phase is therefore associated with poorer dispersion of the active phase in the catalyst [18]. An indication of such a process is the larger nickel crystallite size for the IMN catalyst among the 5 catalysts (Table 2 ), as discussed by Medeiros et al. (2021) [47] This indicates poorer dispersion of the active phase in the catalyst. High dispersion is an interesting property for DRM catalysts due to the greater availability of active sites providing greater catalytic activity. The dispersion also contributes to coke resistance and consequently to the stability of the catalyst, because due to the greater availability of active sites its performance must be less affected, as the coke encapsulates the active phase particles [58–60]. The bands observed in the region with a number equal to 1260 cm-1 in the FTIR spectra of the catalysts (Fig. 3 a) refer to the vibrational modes of the borate groups (BO3) for catalysts containing boron, a species formed from the thermal decomposition of the H3BO3 [61,62], In Fig. 3b, we observe the same band in the infrared spectrum of boric acid corresponding to the B-O bonds. Such a band confirms the presence of these species under the support for both synthesis methods. The bands at 3400 cm-1 and in the range from 1600 to 1400 cm-1 refer to the vibrational modes of hydroxyl groups on the support or water adsorbed on the catalyst surface [57]. The isotherms presented in Fig. 4 show the characteristic profile of type II isotherms which are common to non-porous and macroporous materials, with a hysteresis loop of type H3, which demonstrates that the material is composed of non-rigid aggregates of plate-like particles. The addition of boron causes a clear decrease in hysteresis resulting in an isotherm similar to type I(b) for the material IMNB-5, predicated for materials with wide variation in pore size, along with values close to narrow mesopores and wide micropores (∼2 nm) [63]. This occurs in the IMNB-5 material due to the occupation of the support pores by boron added through impregnation, as observed in the work carried out by Singh et al. (2020) [29]. This hypothesis is corroborated by the values obtained for total pore volume (Table 3 ); however, this effect is not observed with such intensity in samples synthesized by the One-Pot route, which may be linked to the B2O3 particles not only being allocated in the pores, but in the bulk of the material forming a similar set to a solid solution. Fig. 5 presents the results of the temperature-programmed reduction (TPR-H2) test, which demonstrate a decrease in events related to nickel oxide with weak interaction between the metal and support in the range of 200 to 400 °C [64] for materials containing boron. As reported by Ni et al. (2012)[44], the formed borates have a strong interaction with nickel, reducing its contact with the support and compromising this interaction, leading to significant sintering over the long term. Among the materials with boron content, the absence of this event is observed for the samples synthesized by the one-pot method, indicating that all the nickel in these catalysts is in an environment of medium and strong interaction with the support (Al2O3). This increased interaction may suppress sintering at the reaction temperature [64–66]. This alleviates the sintering problem caused by the promotion with B2O3. The absence of the first peak in the MONB catalysts could be due to diffusion difficulties of H2, considering that the materials synthesized by the one-pot method have all their components (NiO, Al2O3, and B2O3) formed together during the combustion reaction. Therefore, the NiO particles are not necessarily on the surface but rather within the bulk of the material [67]. The consumption of H2 (Table 4 ) highlights the lower availability of nickel in catalysts containing boric oxide, which can be attributed to the stronger interaction between nickel and borates [44] in the case of MONB materials, in addition to the Ni-B interaction, the formation of bulk occurs at high combustion temperatures elevates interaction metal-support [68], This is evidenced by the shift of the peaks to higher temperatures. Another aspect is the diffusion difficulty caused by the insertion of boron into the subsurface vacancies of the nickel particles [39,40,42]. 3.2 Catalytic stability test The performance of the catalysts in the reaction is shown in Fig. 6 . The IMN catalyst presents the highest initial methane conversion rate ∼80 %, with the drop in catalytic activity for methane due to restricting the amount of Ni impregnated, considering that it is responsible for the methane dehydrogenation reaction [18] Another aspect which explains the drop in activity in these catalysts is the greater energy required for methane dehydrogenation in Ni catalysts promoted by boron [39]. Conversely, the initial conversion of CO2 increases for the promoted catalysts, which can be attributed to the amphoteric nature of boron trioxide which is capable of providing a more basic surface for the catalyst and contributing to adsorption of the CO2 [69,70]. The IMN material suffers more significantly from deactivation (10.40 %) throughout the catalysis process, while the catalysts promoted by B2O3 demonstrate greater stability in the reaction process, as shown in Fig. 7 . The best performance was obtained by the MONB-25 catalyst with deactivation of (1.02 %) during 12 h of reaction, resulting in a catalyst 10.20 times more stable than the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst and 2.41 times more stable than the IMNB-25 material synthesized by impregnation route. These results show a greater tendency towards stability for the promoted materials in relation to the material without a promoter, as well as greater stability for the catalysts synthesized by the one-pot route. The main routes for deactivating catalysts in DRM are coke formation from the methane dehydrogenation reactions (Eq. (7)) and the Boudouard reaction (Eq. (8)), as well as sintering from the process temperature [71]. (7a) CH4 → C + 2H2 (8) 2CO → C + CO2 The high stability of the promoted catalysts can be attributed to the anti-coke action exerted by boron, as explained by Xu & Saeys (2006, 2007) [39,40]. This effect can be observed in the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) presented in Fig. 8 , in which the difference in coke formed by the standard Ni/Al2O3 catalyst in relation to catalysts promoted by B2O3 is clear; as a result, the increase in the amount of B2O3 leads to lower mass losses relative to inorganic carbon, reducing the amount of coke formed for the MONB-5 catalyst by a factor of 5.4, and by a factor of 2.4 in relation to the IMNB-5 catalyst. This phenomenon was observed in several studies that used boron as catalytic promoter for DRM [29,41–43,72]. The effect of suppressing inorganic carbon formation is due to the boron particles accommodated in the subsurface layers of the nickel particles, thereby preventing diffusion and growth of carbon particles, in turn preventing their crystallization and enabling improved gasification mechanisms of this coke [39,40]. This argument is supported by the XRD and Raman analyzes after the reaction (Fig. 9 ), in which the catalysts containing B2O3 have a lower intensity of the peak 2θ = 26.2° relative to the graphitic carbon identified by the PDF 01–075–1621 crystallographic chart [41] and a higher disorder degree of the carbon than that of the standard catalyst attested by the ratio between the D band for disordered carbon and the G band for graphitic carbon [73,74] The decreased crystallinity in the formed carbon plays an important role in gasification of the formed carbon, as the more crystalline the carbon, the greater the energy demand for its removal from the catalyst surface [42,75]. A relevant aspect is that the basicity of the B-OH groups is higher than the basicity of the Al-OH groups, which improves the coke gasification mechanism by forming methanoate species (CHxO) from the reaction between dehydrogenated methane (CHx) and the supporting OH groups; such methanoate groups readily decompose into CO and adsorbed H [44], which may explain the lower coke deposition for catalysts synthesized by the one-pot route with the tendency for greater dispersion (Table 2) of borate groups resulting in a greater area of available OH groups. The one-pot synthesis via microwave combustion leads to the formation of a material as a solid solution of oxides, providing high dispersion of the components. This dispersion creates more active sites, which increase the efficiency to both for the dissociative adsorption of CH4 on nickel particles and for the conversion of CO2 at the metal-support interface, which results in higher efficiency in the oxidative processes of the formed coke. [44,47,76]. Filamentous carbon had its presence verified in all catalysts after the catalytic tests in the FE-SEM micrographs (Fig. 10 ). Such nanotube morphology is also confirmed in the Raman analysis by the presence of the G and D’ bands attributed to forming carbon nanotubes [77] and originates from the diffusion of carbon between nickel particles, as advocated by Rostrup-Nielsen [78]. These species are responsible for removing nickel particles from the support, thus reducing the number of active sites on the catalyst surface which compromises performance. As reported by Ni et al. (2012) [44] the addition of B2O3 leads to weakening the Ni-Al2O3 interaction, causing greater deactivation through sintering of active phase particles. This process is responsible for the superior deactivation of catalysts with greater amounts of B2O3 (IMNB-5 and MONB-5), as observed in Fig. 7. In contrast, one-pot synthesis can provide greater interaction between the active phase and the support; as reported by Medeiros et al. (2021) [47] in their programmed reduction temperature test, there is the occurrence of a single reduction event for the material synthesized with fuel deficit (as well as the MONB-25 and MONB-5 materials in this work) in the temperature region of 650 °C relative to reduction of the NiO species with strong interaction with the support. However, this is different from the results obtained by the wet impregnation method as performed by Maziveiro et al. (2021) [32], Bui et al. (2023) [79] and this work for samples IMNB-25 e IMNB-5 (Fig. 5) in which the most prominent H2 consumption peaks for the NiO phase are in the temperature region of 360 °C, which demonstrates that the greater metal-support interaction provided by the one-pot synthesis method by microwave-assisted combustion can result in a catalyst that is less susceptible to sintering and more stable. 4 Conclusion Promotion by B2O3 and the one-pot synthesis route were able to add properties to the catalysts which improved their performance in terms of stability, thus guaranteeing the material's lifetime under reaction conditions which can significantly contribute to its use in larger synthesis gas production scales. Boron promotion was able to reduce coke deposition by up to ∼82 % and increase the disorder degree of the formed carbon by preventing diffusion and cristalization of the coke formed. In addition, the one-pot synthesis method improved the specific surface area of the catalysts while maintaining and increasing the pore volume, which is due to the boron species being dispersed in the bulk of the material and not blocking the pores on the surface as in the impregnated material. This synthesis method improves the metal-support interaction, which in turn guarantees better resistance to sintering, even with the addition of the boron promoter. The combination of these properties guarantees >10 times greater stability for the MONB-25 catalyst in relation to the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. CRediT authorship contribution statement Yuri K.R.O. coredata.dc:description: The production of hydrogen from dry reforming of methane (DRM) is crucial for the energy transition, aiming for a more sustainable energy matrix due to its similarity to biogas reforming, which provides a renewable substrate for large-scale synthesis gas production. In this context, the efficiency of catalysts plays a fundamental role in optimizing this process, considering the extreme operational conditions in terms of temperature and competing reactions. This study investigates the synthesis, characterization, and stability of nickel catalysts supported on alumina, using a one-pot synthetic approach via microwave-assisted combustion, compared to catalysts synthesized by the commonly used wet impregnation method. Structural characterization was performed using X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR-H2). Textural properties were assessed through nitrogen (N2) adsorption. The results showed that the catalysts synthesized by the one-pot method tend to have a high dispersion of nickel particles and a larger surface area, contributing to superior catalytic activity. Catalytic stability tests revealed that the catalysts promoted with B2O3 exhibited lower deactivation and reduced coke formation compared to unpromoted catalysts; however, an increase in the amount of B2O3 raised deactivation due to sintering, which was mitigated by the one-pot method that enhances metal-support interaction. The one-pot synthetized nickel catalyst with 2.5 wt% stood out, with stability more than ten times greater than that of the conventional Ni/Al2O3 catalyst and four times greater than the promoted catalyst synthesized via impregnation. Among the 3 catalysts mentioned, the final CH4 conversions were 78 %, 72 %, and 75 %, respectively, while the H2 yields were 60 %, 55 %, and 58 % after 12 h of reaction. The findings indicate that promotion with B2O3 and the one-pot synthesis significantly improved the stability and efficiency of the catalysts, offering potential for larger-scale synthesis gas production applications.
